ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: NEAT enhancements

All technical indicators are based on some combination of open, close, 
high, low and volume. I like the approach taken in the book 'Blondie24' 
- give the neural net just the basic info and allow it to combine it as 
it sees fit. The net may come up with an amazing new indicator within 
it's weights that no-one has thought of before. I think it's better to 
put as little human knowledge in there as possible and allow it to 
discover things for itself.
I've been working on my own little project for ages now - I keep 
stopping and restarting and redoing things so my progress has been terrible!
Again, using Blondie24 as my inspiration, I'm intending to give the last 
'N' days (N to be determined - but after looking at at Sidhant's paper, 
I might borrow the concept of adding input nodes so that neat would come 
up with an optimal value of N for itself) of open, high, low, close & 
volume as input to the net, and getting the output to be -1 to +1 to 
represent a strong sell signal through to a strong buy signal.
Assuming that I can get a net that can give good buy / sell signals 
based on what the normalised stock graph I show it as input looks like, 
I'll then run it against every stock in the FTSE All-Share say each 
night then look at the top 10 stocks ranked by net output to see if I 
fancy buying any of them.
I have perl programs to site-scrape all the historic data off 
finance.yahoo.com. I'm in the middle of donwloading it all - which 
according to my estimates will take about a month of constant 
downloading to get the whole lot!.
All I need now is to get off my arse and finish the thing!!
Part of the delay is that I'm trying to write my own implementation of 
neat in C++ which borrows heavily from SharpNEAT, but keep getting side 
tracked.
I'm cutting out all the recurrent stuff - I don't need it for my 
purposes. Consequently the Neural Net's are Directed Acyclic Graphs, and 
using that fact enables me to make some good optimisations over a more 
general neat that includes recurrency.
Yes - I should be using an 'off-the-shelf' version of neat and just 
getting on with things, but half the fun is writing my own version ;-)

Cheers,
Emyr

Matt Simmerson wrote:
>
> Hi Sidhant
>
> Great paper. I have been trying to do much the same thing, except
> rather than value prediction, I have been creating a trader that
> essentially decides to go short, long or take the 5th ;). I've had
> mixed success, and not had the confidence to actually lay any money
> out yet. It would be interesting to know what input data sets have
> you been using for the Forex part of your paper, as I have tried all
> sorts of things including technical indicators etc.
>
> Cheers
>
> Matt
>
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com>, Sidhant 
> Dash <sidhantdash@...> wrote:
> >
> > As part of an undergraduate research project, I did implement
> something on those lines.
> >
> > I worked on a NEAT based approach to predicting a noisy financial
> time series (Yen-USD exchange rate). The original NEAT algorithm was
> modified to start with an initial population of 3 different neural
> network architectures, which included Elman networks and MLPs apart
> from the normal recurrent networks that NEAT begins with. The networks
> (winners) produced by NEAT were then put through a conjugate gradient
> based optimization process, and finally the optimized networks were
> combined using an ensembling technique to produce the final results.
> >
> > I personally think the local optimization is necessary when we are
> using NEAT to produce networks to accomplish tasks that require a high
> degree of precision. It kind of fine tunes the performance of the
> networks. Ensembling then is one of the standard tools in the ML
> repertoire to produce results that none of NEAT's 'winner' networks
> could individually produce.
> >
> > A detailed project report is posted in the Files section.
> >
> > regards
> > Sidhant
> >
> > aklein07 <a.klein@...> wrote:
> > All,
> >
> > Ken's papers mention (at least I think that they do) that (dynamic)
> > annealing of mutation rates might be advantageous in order to confine
> > global searching after a while to a promising region in search space.
> > Having read some papers, I also found indications that a hybrid
> > weight training algorithm (global search by means of genetic
> > algorithms and local search using some gradient descent algorithm)
> > might be able to produce better results than genetic algorithm search
> > alone. The reason is, that each type of algorithm performs well
> > mostly only in its specific field. Has anyone further insights into
> > this topic ? Has anyone tried to implement any of the approaches
> > mentioned ?
> >
> > Also time delay network connections might provide improvements for
> > some model estimation tasks. Has anyone tested / implemented yet any
> > of these ideas ?
> >
> > Thanks for any comments,
> > Achim
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
